reviews.text: It's so quiet. You can shop for hrs without fear of ever getting caught in a crowd.
Buses where on strike so got the train and the guard was really helpful even give me 50p has I was short of money so I would say thanks to the man and I would use the station again.

Could be better, staff seem like it a chore working, not as nice to wait as years ago when staff were friendlier, costs nothing to smile. The lifts always seem slow and like they are struggling, doubt they even been updated since 1990 either.

Had the worst experience, the guy in the booth was VERY rude and sold me a ticket to a train thats been cancelled, and was being soo rude about it, dont know if there is a way i can report him. His parents didnt tech him any manners at all

Both me and my sister are disabled with disabled train passes and literally every time we have the misfortune of having to go through Bolton they fanny about, pretend they can't see us, take ages to open the gate both in and out of the train station and just generally bad attitudes, the platform staff aren't much better; my sister has a walking stick and the conductor on the platform staff will just stand idley by as she's pushed around and pushed off the train to be the only one left on the platform, one actually tried to justify this by saying "well there were no seats left anyway" funny because I thought priority seats were for disabled people.

This station didn't used to be that bad but  it's truly awful now and as a disabled person I dread going through it.
